Remtd 7th Oct/ 63

Burlington Ky
Oct 3d 1863
His Excellency Thos E Bramlet Gov of Ky
Sir:

Last winter a man by the name of Geo Smith was committed to the jail of Boone County on a charge of felony & T J & M Carpenter were recognized as witnesses to the April term of the Court Court 1863 in bonds of one hundred dollars each A short time before the April term Smith was busted & both the Carpenters attended at the County seat of said County on monday the commencement day of said term & the judge failing to arrive during the day the witnesses afsd as well as the people generally left the county seat with the understanding there would be no court The judge arrived about nine oclock next morning when it was greed by the members of the bar remaining -- that failing to open court on the first day no court could be held for that term & thereupon the judge issued an order giving a special term of said court the 3d Monda in May at which time the Carpenters failing to appear their recognizance was forfeited & summons against them to the Sept term when they appeared & testified before the Grand Jury who failing to indict Smith he was discharged T J Carpenter answered to the summons that his family were sick at the time & was exhonerated by the Court Woodford Carpenter the other witness was less fortunate & simply
gave an excuse for failing to attend the May term "that he had forgotten the time of holding the called term" The Judge thinking this an insufficient excuse witheld judgment against him for one hundred dollars & cost Mr Carpenter came back on the 9th day of the term to ask the Court to set aside the judgment against but the court had then adjorned He says that upon reflection that he did not know or hear of the special tirm in May ^until the evening of the adjornment^ which I believe is true for he lives remotely from the Court house & there were very few persons in his part of the county attending that term til thursday I believe the day the court was adjorned many of those coming in saying they had just hourd there was a court There were many not only in that portion of the County but in other portions men hostile to the appointed Judge as they called Judge Drone who In my opinion did not to say the least wish to give much countenance to his Court & would readily frame such excuses as want of knowledge of the time of holding the Court But Mr Carpenter does not belong to or sympathise with any such class or party I have known Mr Carpenter long & intimately & from knowledge of the man do not believe he would make a false statement intentionally to be relieved of such a fine & when he now says that he did not know of the setting of the Court til the evening of its adjorunment I believe him & so believing do not hesitate to ask you to believe him He certainly meant no contempt He is a law abiding Union man who suffered no little by Kirby Smith army while in our County. He has already paid J. L. Scott atty for the Commlth the amount going to him & asks your excellency to relieve him from the ballance Before you determine please have a conversation with Mr Scott who will I am confident endorse my statement.
